comment.author: 13070533@N07
comment._content: The Drum Major is wearing State Dress minus the white spatterdash gaiters that should in principle go with it. He is in fact from the Scots Guards, as the print is just clear enough to make out the thistle in the centre of the star on the baldric or cross belt. Although the relevant part of the monogram is obscured, I'd say that the photograph was taken either before or shortly after the death of Queen Victoria in 1901, as the baldric bears the "Queen's crown". The architecture in the background suggests the Tower of London as a possible location.

comment.author: 63385174@N06
comment._content: I dont want to step on anyone's toes, however I have to say that the tunic is too large for him. These tunics are ALWAYS tailor made for the individual who wears them. If re-cycled, they are tailored again to fit perfectly. The tunic in this picture is far too large to be adjusted for the wearer. Slacker is not a term that comes to mind when I think of Drum Major. I doubt any Drum Major would pose for a photograph without wearing the full kit, with spatterdash gaiters (white leggings). The gentleman in the picture may well be Army, however I doubt very much it is his uniform. If it was a rush for the funeral, the tailors would have worked day and night (on a closer fitting tunic) to get a proper fitting kit for such a prominent participant in the ceremonies.

comment.author: 40042677@N02
comment._content:
As I served as a Drummer in the Grenadier Guards, I have to add my comments as well.  
Although this may possibly be a 'Posed' photo by someone having a bit of fun, it's doubtful any good Drum Major would leave his expensive State Dress, made from real gold wire, laying around for someone to do so. 
There are many faults in this photo, not only is the uniform to large for this person, which has previously been remarked on, but he appears to be totally in the wrong order of dress. He is not wearing white leather leggings and garters, he's not wearing a Skirt, he's wearing Shoes instead of Boots, and the most obvious fault of all is: although this photo states a Grenadier Drum Major London, he is in fact wearing what I believe to be a Scots Guards crossbelt or Sash, (or it could possibly be a Coldstream Guards one,) and is certainly not wearing a Grenadier Guards Drum Major's Sash!
